chapter.title: Making use of Relations
chapter.para: CG-3 can also work with generic relations. These are analogous to dependency relations, but can have any name, overlap, are directional, and can point to multiple cohorts.

section.title: SETRELATION, SETRELATIONS
section.para: SETRELATION creates a one-way named relation from the current cohort to the found cohort. The name must be an alphanumeric string with no whitespace.
SETRELATIONS creates two one-way named relation; one from the current cohort to the found cohort, and one the other way. The names can be the same if so desired.

section.title: REMRELATION, REMRELATIONS
section.para: REMRELATION destroys one direction of a relation previously created with either SETRELATION or SETRELATIONS.
REMRELATIONS destroys both directions of a relation previously created with either SETRELATION or SETRELATIONS.

section.title: Existing Relations in Input
section.para: Not currently supported; relations from input are ignored at present stage of development.

section.title: Contextual Tests
section.para: Once you have relations to work with, you can use that in subsequent contextual tests as seen below. These positions can be combined with the window spanning options.

section.title: Specific Relation
section.para: The 'r:rel' position asks for cohorts found via the 'rel' relation. 'rel' can be any name previously given via SETRELATION or SETRELATIONS. Be aware that for combining positional options, 'r:rel' should be the last in the position; 'r:' will eat anything following it until it meets a space.

section.title: Any Relation
section.para: The 'r:*' position asks for cohorts found via any relation.
